titleStmt.title: The last newes from Bohemia, with all the adioyning prouinces that be now vp in armes. Wherein is related all the passages that haue happened since the high and mighty prince elector Palatine of the Rhine was elected and crowned King of Bohemia. With other accidents very delightfull to the reader..

The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The last newes from Bohemia, with all the adioyning prouinces that be now vp in armes. Wherein is related all the passages that haue happened since the high and mighty prince elector Palatine of the Rhine was elected and crowned King of Bohemia. With other accidents very delightfull to the reader..

Reproduction of original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: THE Last Newes from BOHEMIA, with all the adioyning Prouinces that be now vp in Armes.
Wherein is related all the passag • s that haue happened since the high and mighty Prince Elector PALATINE of the Rhine was elected and Crowned King of BOHEMIA.
With other accidents very delightfull to the Reader.

div.head: THE LAST NEWES from BOHEMIA with all the adioyning Prouinces, that be now vp in Armes.
div.p:
SIr, &c, The newes in Germany is, that Bethlem Gaber Prince of Transiluania vnderstanding of the troublesome state of Bohemia, and of the adiacent Prouinces his confederates, with a great Army that he had gathered about Clandiople, made an inrode into the higher Hungaria, taking along with him eighteene peices of great Ordinance: with this his vnexpected comming he presently obtained of the Nobilitie, whom hee had made afraide, and who possessed these places, that they should
ioyne with him. But he constrained Human • ie (who for a while resisted him, yet not being of sufficient strength to hold out,) to depart into P • l •• ia.

Then for the taking in of Cassouie, Rede, and Se • s • h, Coronels being sent by Bethlem Gahor Prince of Transiluania with an Army, required that the Captaine, who was within the Citie Dots should be deliuered into their power, this threatning being added, that except hee aliue were permitted vnto them, they would spare neither infants nor sucking babes. Who therefore receiuing him into their power, disrobed and mocked him, and so sent him into Transylvania. The Citie it selfe when it could not preuaile against this force, and knew of no helpe, vpon deliberation had, yeelded vnto the forces of Bethlem Gaber Prince of Transiluania, taking an oath to him and to the States of Hungary, vpon the fift of September, great terror was throughout all Hungary vpon this iourney and inrode, the Loilars and other Ecclesiasticall persons, because they sawe Monasteries, and whole Bishoprickes to be inuaded, Monkes and Canons to be gelded, and great outrage euery where to bee exercised, fearing violence to be offred vnto themselues, in great number did withdraw themselues out of this Prouince.

The Emperour after the Coronation departing
from Franckfor •
vpon the eight of September, came to Au • burg vpon the eighteenth of September, and there taking an oath set forward to Monach and to Grece.

Bu • quoy in the meane space after he had taken in P • ssec in Bohemia, appointed to march towards
• habor: but being preuented by the Bohemians, hee pitched his Campe at Merouits. Thether also the Bobemians followed him, opposing their Campe vnto his, and obseruing all his endeauours: whereupon sundry times they fought, and when vpon the fourth of September, a troupe of Spaniards went somewhat too farre from the Campe, they falling vpon the Bohemians, lost about fiue hundred Souldiers.

At what time Bucquoy had receiued inteligence that Ferdinando was elected Emperour, in the night that followed the seuenth day of September, he set his Army in array, thrice shooting of all his Ordinance and Gunnes, in signe of ioy; but the Bohemians, who were ignorant of this thing, all the night standing in battle aray, expected what might befall. Both sides kept themselues within their campes, vntill of a sudden Bucquoy receiued a message from the Arch-Duke Leopold, whereby hee was admonished of the vnexpected entrie of Bethlem Gaber Prince of Transiluania into Hungary, and was commaunded to lead his Army
into lower Austria, and there to fortifie the castles and chiefe townes. But before hee went out of Bohemia, he assaulted the castle Rosenberg, pertaining to Suanberg, and taking it, sent away the Souldiers with bagge and baggage. A Garrison being put therein, hee departed with his Army out of the Kingdome, and stopped vp all the passages whereby the Bohemians might followe after him, who were constrained by going about to goe to helpe the Morauians, after they had heard of the warre there. After his departure the Bohemians sent part of their Army to recouer Bechin, which towne Bucquoy had taken in vpon the thirteenth of August, and by enforcing open a gate through an engine, they tooke it, the Garrison Souldiers for the most part being slaine, and the Captaine and the Ancient being sent to Prague.
After they recouered Thine by composition, which towne Bucquoy had taken in vpon the seuenteenth of August. On the other side Tampir tooke Lundeburg with no small losse of his owne men.

Affaires being framed at Cassoue according to the desire of Bethlem Gaber Prince of Transiluania, and most of the cities, for Myne being bound to him by oath, Satch and Rede with eighteene thousand souldiers strong, and with two great pieces entred vpon all places round about, and also vpon Fillec. Thence hee wrote
to the adioyning cities, that they should not resist, but that willingly they should admit the gouernment of the Transiluanians, affirming that this iourney was made with the foreknowledge and consent of the Christian States, and threatning all extremities to those that resisted.

This Proclamation being receiued, they subdued very many cities and castles; namely Vaccium, Tirnaue, Nentre, Nouigrade, Possing and others, the Heiduckes of Iarm • th apprehending their owne Captaine, and deliuering him vp to their power, with the Fort.

Afterwards Newhouse was taken in, and the Gouernour of the Garrison souldiers being bound in fetters, and depriued of all his moueables, was sent to Cassoue: where a little before, namely vpon the first of September the Transiluanians triumphed with so great discharging of Ordinance, that the noyse thereof reached vnto Comorch; which Fort, as also Ianrin haue abode constant in their loyaltie towards the Emperour, although the Transiluanians had possessed the Ile, and so had opened a passage for themselues to other places.

When the Palatine P. Elector was certified of his election made by the States of Bohemia, hee iudged not rashly to aduenture thereon, not being ignorant with how great molestations, cares, labours and daungers this dignitie was
ioyned, therefore he beganne to call this businesse into deliberation, and to consult thereof with Princes and States who were allied vnto him by kindred and acquaintance, and commaunded that publicke prayer should be made upon certaine dayes through his whole countrey.

At length hee being mooued with certaine reasons, thought it fit to obey the will of God and his vocation. Therefore the affaires in the Palatineship being set in order, and the politicall gouernment being committed to Iohn Bipont, and matters of warre being referred to Iohn Nassawe the elder, with the Princesse, with his children, and with his whole house hee went to Amberg.
They of Brussles were saide about this time to be entred into sedition, because of exactions, and of publicke impositions: but the multitudes of Spanish souldiers gathering head quieted them.

Bucquoy vpon his forsaking of Bohemia, tooke in Horne a towne of lower Austria, and placed a Garrison therein: but after obseruing that it could not bee retained, the Garrison being called away, vpon the fift of October hee came to Ret • , and after to Sname a towne in Morauia, with nine thousand horse and foote, and presently with great importunitie demanded that their towne should bee deliuered vp.
But when the Garrison, these threatnings being neglected, prepared for defence, and knewe that twelue thousand Hungarians and Transiluanians were ready at hand, hee raised the Campe and departed, to ioyne himselfe with Tampier.

In the meane space the Transiluanians drew neare, and ioyned themselues with the Bohemian and Morauian Campe. This beeing knowne, some ensignes of the Hungarians who were vnder Tampier, leauing his Campe reuoulted to the Transiluanians. When therefore Turren sawe that his Army was augmented with the Hungarians and Transiluanians to be about twentie sixe thousand, vpon deliberation with Rede hee determined to meete and to fight with Bucquoy and Tampier. But for to try their strength Tampier sent foorth three Companies, which for the most part were slaine by the Hungarians. Whereupon Bucquoy seeing himselfe too weake, the former station being left, pitched his campe at the outer bridge of Danow, whither Leopold the Arch-Duke came from Vienna to view the Army. But the enemy with great fury pursuing the rereward put to flight, fiue hundred of the Tampiers company.

But presently the Bohemians comming forward, and the Mountaine and the next Wood being possessed, they drew nearer and
nearer towards them. Leopold preswaded Buequoy to fight, and to try the very extremity: but he refusing the counsell that was ioyned with very great perill, kept himselfe in the campe: but yet the Archduke being returned into the cittie, the Battle beganne about euening, and was continued vntill about midnight, the Artilerie on both sides being discharged, with no small losse vpon both sides.

The next day, when for a thicke mist they could not looke about, and when they thought that the Bohemians were retired, to passe ouer Danow at Fischet, and with their campe to possesse the other side of the Riuer, Bucquoy sent his Souldiers to stop that passage. But after the mist breaking vp, when they who were in the Vauntgard had already gotten ouer the Bridge with many Gunnes, and the Rereward was yet in the campe at the Bridge, the Bohemians in great number comming vpon them, endeauoured to take the bridge from them. Whereupon a great fight was made, and a great company on both sides were slaine with the often shooting of Gunnes. The greatest losse fell out in the campe of Bucquoy, three barrels of Gunpowder being fired by negligence of souldiers, which not onely killed many but caused those that were scorched in quenching the fire, to bee drowned in Danow.

Bucquoy, Dampier, and other captaines diligently encouraged their souldiers to fight, and sustained the Enemy vntill night, which comming on, when they saw that the fort raised before the Bridge was assaulted, with great courage they tooke thence the Garrison, ouerthrew the bridge, and so betooke themselues to rest. Whilest the skirmish lasted, the Hungarians that yet remained in the campe of Dampier, the carriages which they were set to keepe, being ranfacked and fired betook themselues to flight. The number that were slaine was vncertaine, for the wounded the next day in many waines were carried to Vienna, who afterwards dyed in great number. Bucquoy himselfe was wounded in the arme with a bullet, and his chiefe Colonel was wounded thrice, but dyed not.

Bethlem Gaber Prince of Transiluania, in the meane space with a great army that he conducted went towards Poson, and tooke the Castle of Petronel by force, which he rased. This rumour comming to Vienna, three companies of Souldiers with three brazen pieces being shipped were sent into Poson, and entred into the suburbs vpon the thirteenth of October. This night was very tempestuous, therefore the Trans • iuanians, preassed vpon them fearing no such thing, and put to flight a great part of these souldiers, their captaine T • esenbach with
a fewe escaping by flight. The Suburb being taken, Bethlem Gaber Prince of Transiluania commaunded the Prince Palatine to answere him, whether hee would defend the citie and the castle, or that he should yeelde without force, certaine dayes being permitted for deliberation, who taking aduice with Palse and with others of the Nobilitie, when hee could doe none other, determined to yeelde. Therefore the citie being taken in, the Prince of Transiluania commanded that a Sermon should bee made in the Cathedrall Church vpon the twenty of October, and thence passing into the castle viewed the Crowne of Hungary, and the other ornaments of the Kingdome, and returning into the citie entertained the Prince Palatine and other Nobles to dinner.

In the meane space the Palatine P. Elector the elected K. of Bohemia departing from Amberg came to Waltsachs, where the Embassadors of the Prouinces vnited into Bohemia, met him, with eighteene coaches: thence they went to Egra, thence to Falquenaue and to Sant, and so to other places with the gratulation and ioy of all citizens, vntill at length he came to Prague, into which he entred with very great pompe, and a little after was present in their Parleament.

Ernest Count Mansfield that he might recouer places taken in by Bucquoy, vpon the three
and twentith of October went with his Souldiers to Winterburg, and presently a Fort and the chappell being taken that was builded vnder the castle, he exhorted the Captaine to yeelde, and when hee saide hee would rather loose his life then gratifie his enemy: the Count battering the gate entred, and slewe all the Garrison, except a fewe Prisoners.

This being done, other townes and places yeelded of their owne accord, their garrisons passing to Budwitz. Thence the Count going to Pragadit, and finding the garrison to resist, with great violence tooke the towne and slewe them all vpon the twenty foure of October.

Herman Frence, a garrison being left in Thabor, went with his Army towards Wodian, and knowing that the captaine of this towne was not furnished with a sufficient guard, and that two Noble men of Bohemia, who had hitherto serued vnder the Emperour, were gone into this towne, all passages being besieged, tooke order to beate all the souldiers from the towers and walles, and to burst open a gate; but throgh valiant resistance of the garrison could doe no good, vntill the next day a Trumpetour being sent, the Captaine couenanted to depart: which Frence willingly permitted; yet so that they should deliuer the two Noble-men, who, the towne being taken in, were carried and put into the tower at Prage: where in the meane
season Fredericke P. Elector Palatine was crowned King of Bohemia, in Nouember: and in the same moneth Elizabeth his wife, Princesse of Great Britain was crowned Queene.
At this time in France Conac was set at libertie, and some perswaded, that neither side of the Germans was to be holpen, because France had receiued no small profit from the Princes thereof.

Great calamity did now also oppresse lower Austria, the souldiers on euery side meeting there, and wonderfully exasperating this mischiefe, but the inhabitants in great-number with their wiues and children fled to other places.

At Vienna the souldiers of Bucquoy, and of Dampier, wasted the villages and other townes, that no profit might thence redound to the enemy, insomuch that victuals encreased still their price at Vienna; furthermore from higher Austria an Army was sent vnder the Generall Sterenberg, who preserued passage to both the bankes of Danow, by wasting and taking in the villages and townes that appertained to the Catholickes: but they commaunding the Monastery of Molque to yeelde, and not being obeyed fired the towne, and assaulted the castle, vntill they were hindered by fowle weather.

Bucquoy and Dampier vnderstanding that the
Hungarians at Poson, passing ouer Danow had put to flight Hainburg the Coronell in open warre, thought fit to succour him with some certaine thousands, and with sixe hundred barded horse.

Therefore they ioyning battle, many were slaine on both sides, and Bucquoy was stricken on his Armour with a short sword, and very many were wounded, who were afterwards carried to Vienna: but a thousand and six hundred of the troopes of Bucquoy passed away to the Hungarians their countrey-men.

Vpon the moneth of Nouember the Protestants assembled a Parlement at Norimberg, where the King of Bohemia, and many other great Princes met, and gaue answere to the Embassadours of the Emperour: who, vpon the twenty foure of Nouember came from Greatz to Vienna, where hee was entertained by Leopold the Arch-Duke.

Capisan a certaine Captaine of the Bohemian forces comming with foure thousand to Creames, opened one gate with Artillery, and the other with fire: but yet could not take the citie because of the Port-cullis: not onely the souldiers, but also the women powred scalding liquor, and pitch-barrels vpon their heads, so that they were constrained to retire with the losse of some two hundred.

After this there came from Millain ouer
the Alpes through Heluetia into the Bishopricke of Passawe, about eight thousand souldiers strong, and markes of greatest crueltie being left there, when they could not passe into higher Austria, because that all the passages were stopped by the countrey people, some of them passed towards Budwitz in Bohemia, vnder Coronell Balthasar.

The Emperour being come into Vienna, the Hungarians and Bohemians in great number marched towards Nischet, and thence towards Vienna by Ebersdorfe, which they tooke in, sending the garrison to Vienna, and so spoiled all the villages and townes, not without great slaughter.

Thereupon the countrey people in great companies came into Vienna, and made victuals exceeding deare. Turren and Bethlem Gaber, Prince of Transyluania, who had besieged the citie, affirming for certain, that if the consorts of their Religion had not beene therein, they would haue constrained them to haue yeelded through famine.

In the meane space Humanoie with eight thousand Polonians to trie his destinie, made an inrode into Hungary: but by Ragots, whom the Prince of Transiluania had left at Cassoue, he being subdued lost a company of his souldiers.

Thereupon ioyning forces with Radulen, and
Count Althem, hauing ten thousand souldiers, hee againe marched against him. A great battle being fought and continued all night long, some three thousand were slaine vpon both sides.

Then the Polonians departing and counterfeiting flight, presently the Hungarian foote fell vpon the spoile: but they were for the most part slaine by the Polonians, who returned againe, and the Hungarian horse fled. Ragots escaping by flight, sought to repaire his Army.

Neuerthelesse the Prince of Transiluania vnderstanding of this slaughter, ceased to besiege Vienna (Rede being sent with part of the Army into vpper Hungarie,) and returned to Poson, Edenburg being by composition taken in, and fortified with a Garrison of foure hundred souldiers.

Also Count Mansfield tooke in Pessec, the garrison being sent away with their Armes; but the Captaine, who was a Spaniard, and valiantly had sustained the siege by the space of a moneth: was carried to Pilsne, and the towne that was made desolate by the imperials, was repaired and fortified with a stronger garrison.

In the moneth of December a great gaping appeared in the skie, in the fashion of Armies comming from the South and North, and
fighting each with other, vntill the Southerne army was ouercome and put to flight.
Vpon the sixteenth of December Iohn-Charles the elder sonne of the Emperor dyed at Greatz.

In the meane space at Prague, by the commandement of the King of Bohemia, being returned from the Parliament of Noremberg Images and Statues, with all Altars were remoued from the Cathedrall Church of the Tower, the Kings Chaplaine making a Sermon, and laying downe the cause of that businesse amongst others, because the King could no longer for his conscience beare Idolatrie in his sight.

Also the King vpon inquisition made, into the corners of Rogues and of Whoores, commanded the Citie to be purged from all filthynesse and dishonesty, and that an Hospitall should bee builded for the poore and aged.
Vpon the twenty seuenth of December a Sonne was borne to the King of Bohemia, for which cause, congratulation was made by the Officers, and prayers were made to God.

On the other side, no small helpe was decreed to the Emperour by the King of Spaine, and the Pope commanded no small contribution to Spirituall and Ecclesiasticall persons through Italie, Spaine, Brabant, Flanders and other prouinces.
The prince Elector of Saxonie is said to be Neuter, and onely prepareth to defend himselfe.

Bucquoy making an inrode towards vpper Austria, tooke Ipsen, a towne that was destitute of Garrison. But before his comming, Sterenberg, the chiefe Generall of this prouince (the fiedge of the Monastery Molque being raised) returned to the limits with his Army, to wait for the cōming of Bucquoy. In the meane season, the countrie people led with the zeale of Religion, killed and put to flight the Italians that remained of the army of Balthasar, who made inroades from the vpper patt. But Carpezan a Colonell of the Bohemians tooke and rased Gotvien, the most strong Monastery of Lower Austria.

Hitherto a great number of Horse and Foote was gathered for the Emperour, and for the prince of Bauaria, in the Territories of Colen, and in the adioyning countries. For the hindring of these expeditions, the States of the vnited prouinces of the Low Countries; writing once or twice to the Electors of Colen and Triers, exhorted them largely to maintaine the league, and not to permit any thing to be done against their confederates; but most especially, not against the prince Palatine Elector, except they would haue the same to be also done in their prouinces.

Part of this Army set forward vnder the gouernment of Count Liopien, and of the Colonel Lantsb • rger, who when they could not obtaine passage through Hassta, and through the countie of Nassawe, they iourning through Vererave passed into Franconia, and there with great discommodity of the Herbipolensians, because the Army of the vnited Princes & States opposed; they were constrained to abide there some certaine weeks. They were about foure thousand, whom, so many others followed a little after. But the Isenburgensians, and the Hanouians opposing, and not willing in any sort to permit passage, they were constrained to returne the way that they came, and in very cold weather to passe ouer the Rhine. But the prince of Bauaria being certisied of the deniall of passage, presently sent Embassadours, who agreed vpon certaine articles for passage. Which agreement being made, the Army passed to the Bishoprike of Achstelin, and there abode certaine daies, with great losse of the inhabitants.
In the meane space a league was concluded betwixt the Emperor and Bethlem Gaber prince of Transiluanta, vntill the feast of Saint Michael, 1620.

About this time Tifenbach the Colonel of the Mor • uian forces comming with his army to Nicolaisburg, obtained the Towne without any
great labour, but sixe hundred Dampirians defended most valiently the Castle, notwithstanding at length when they had repelled the assailants at certaine times, and had slaine about two hundred, and saw that Ti • enbach endeauoured to enter, by mounting against them thirteene great Gunnes: they being destitute of powder and of other things, requested palee, and couenanted with bag and baggage to depart, except they were relieued within three daies, Count Nagrol with three others, being in the meane space left in the Campe for pledges. When therefore, for the bridge cast downe in Dan • w, they could not receiue aide from Dampier; the time being expired, they yeelded vp the Castle, wherein besides much Wine and corne, there were found eight and thirty great pieces of Ordinance, and moueables belonging to Cardinall Ditrichstein, and a great booty that had been taken by Dampier.

In the former yeare, a grieuous contention did arise betwixt two Noblemen of Bohemia; namely, betwixt Henrie Slavat and Wartenberg, about the deceased Baron of Smirsiscen. For he dying without an Heire, being vnmarried, left two Sisters, and the one that married to Slavat entred as sole Heiresse, but Wartenb •• g entring the castle, freed the other sister long detained in prison, and maried her, and entring
vpon the possession of the castle and towne, bound the sabiects to him with an oath. This vexed Slauat, and therefore he framed his action against him: who being called to Prague appeared there, and put in securitie. But the K. of Bohemia send Commissaries, who should comprimise the case concerning the town and the castle.

But it came to passe whiles these Commissaries were deciding the controuersie for Slauat, and had commaunded the wife of Wartenberg to depart from the towne and castle, and to restore them to Slauat, shee being enflamed with furie animated the souldiers, which shee had there to defend the castle. Therefore one of them entred into the chamber, wherein many barrels of Gun-powder were layed vp, and carelesly moouing a match neare to the powder, set the same on fire, and blew vp the whole castle with all that were therein. Who were all the Commissaries with their seruants and other attendants, about threescore, and also the contending parties; Namely Slauata, and the wife of Wartenberg, with the women, seruants and souldiers which they had with them, besides other hurt that it did in the towne.

The King of Bo • emia in February came to Brinna, and was receiued by the States with great pompe: where he tooke the oath of loyaltie
from the States, and confirmed all priuiledges vnto them, and so set forward into Silesia. Hee being scarce departed, the Cosacces about foure thousand comming from Poland made inrodes into Morauia: but not long tarrying there, their iourney beeing continued night and day, and guides being sent before who had knowledge of the places, the bridges being alwayes ouerthrowne which they had passed, lest any should follow at their backes. In their iourney they ransacked many townes and villages, and amongst them Mescrit, wherein at that very time a marriage of a certaine Noble-man was celebrated, and they tooke a great bootie and braue apparell, which afterwards they sold for a litle at Vienna. The horsemen of Morauia followed them somewhat too late: but yet about midnight ouerthrew them neare to the banke of Danow, vpon the tenth of February, and distressed about a thousand of them, the residue with admiration of all men swimming through Danow, and all ouer wet entring into Vienna, where lodging was assigned to them in the Suburbs.

These souldiers afterwards making inrodes into lower Austria, made all places dangerous, spoiled some fiftie villages of the Protestants, and caused that the countrey people in great number with their wines and children •• ying
into the woods, miserably perished through famine and cold. Eight thousand w • re s • ide to followe after them, therefore the Si • esians and Morauians mustered souldiers to hinder them of passage, and sending messengers to the Prince of Transiluania who req •• sted ayde, and threatned a contrary inrode of Turkes and Tartars into Poland, if it againe should endeauour any thing against his dominion, or the dominion of his confederates, (although the King of Poland answered that he knewe not of their comming) and furthermore sent an embassage vnto Vienna, that except these Cosacces beeing called into the Prouince against the league were againe dimissed, hee would presently come with sixteene thousand Hungarians and helpe the oppressed.
At the same time Bucquoy going about to reuenge the losse that hee had receiued not long before by the Bohemians at Chitse, with eight thousand horse and foote marched towards Langelose.

There were there nine companies in garrison vnder Count Mansfield; but the Count himselfe was gone to Prague. When they came thether, certaine troupes being sent before, and the residue detained in ambush, hee drewe the Mansfieldians out of the towne into the ambush. Therefore a great fight being made, and
the troupes of horse being put to fight, about nine hundred foote were ronted, but the residue escaped with the losse of fiue ensignes, and also foure hundred were slaine vpon the other side.

A few dayes after an assault being made vpon the troupe of Hollach, they ronted threescore. Likewise also the imperiall souldiers who were in garrison at Laea, sallying foorth slewe about two hundred of the Sallernian souldiers: and the Cosacces oppressed and ronted a troupe of Hollaghian horse in a certaine village. Dampier vnderstanding of this successe, ioyned campe with Bucquoy, and determined to march the next way towards Prague, & Bucquoy cōmanded, that each one should prouide himselfe of powder and victuals for the space of six dayes. But Christian Prince Anhalt with the Bohemian and Morauian troupes being gathered together without delay to Egenburg, the officers and souldiers that wandred vp and downe in Prague, being commaunded within the space of twenty foure hours to appeare in the campe, vnder a great penaltie.

In the meane space the Spaniards, whom we saide aboue, vnder the gouernment of Balthasar to haue come to Cruma •• , and to Budwitz, making an inrode towards W •• ian and Praga •• t did mightily molest the inhabitants with spoiling
and fyring, and after the departure of Bucquoy, againe wasted the towne that before had beene repaired.

Vpon the two and twentith of February the souldiers in great abundance set forward from Budwitz, and comming to Thine, which is three miles distant from Thabor, and seated vpon M • ldawe, caused it to yeelde, and gaue leaue to the garrison to depart. But seeing that the towne could not be held, they ransacked and left it, and thence passed to Belieschin and to Wittigaue, returning at length with a great bootie vnto their fellowes: which things caused againe that a mustering was made, and that euery twentieth person was commaunded to bee ready at all times.

After that the King of Bohemia was departed from Morauia he came with great triumph to Vrat • slaue, where foure Canons, an Abbot, and a Prior of the Monasteries appearing in the Court tooke the oath of allegiance, which likewise about noone was done by the citizens.

All things being prosperously done, when in the meane space Embassadours were come from the King of Denmarke to the King of
• ohemia, some were appointed by the Princes of Silesia for an embassage to bee sent to Constantinople, and into Poland, in the name of the King
of Bohemia, and of the incorporated Prouinces: but the King hauing viewed the city all about, and the Cathedrall Church being saluted, also all priuiledges being confirmed; setled himselfe to take a iourney into Lusatta: but newes being receiued of the endeauours of Buequoy, he iudged it better to deferre that iourney vntill another time, and returned to Prague.

The Catholickes againe celebrated a lubily, the Pope so ordering and commaunding, that prayers should be powred forth for the safety of the Emperour, and for the preseruation of Catholicke Religion in the Empire. When this feast, or rather fast to the Catholickes was warned in the Church of Stephan at Vienna about eight of the clocke in the morning vpon the three and twentith of February, thundrings and lightnings were seene altogether in an vnvsuall fashion, not without the great amazement of all.

div.head: A strange rel • tion.
div.p:
In the meane season, Prince Anhalt labouboured by all meanes to hinder Bucquoy (who vpon the twenty fourth of February had lost two hundred Souldiers in assaulting Gre • senstein to no purpose) from comming to Prague. Therefore gathering his Army to Egenb •• g,
he besieged all the passages of that place: furthermore he fought with the Imperials, and nor a few on both sides were slaine, vntill at leng • h they ioyned in maine Battell, wherein Bucquoy his forces were ronted and put to execution, although they were farre more in number.

It is reported that one of the Casacces running, lifted Dampier vpon an horse, and so preserued his life; who afterwards retuning to Vienna, complained much of the improuident care of Buequoy, because hee refused to fight, vntill the Armies were come into straite passages and narrow places.

Bucquoy being fled, a great rich booty was intercepted, the Imperials reuolted; Bohemia, Morauia, Silesia, Lusatia, and Austria, yea, and Hungary, were confirmed to the King of Bohemia, and in a word, all signes of future prosperity profered themselues to him, but the contrary to his enemies.

Yea a little after at Prague a Parliament was kept, wherein they propounded the example of the vnited Prouinces in the Low Countries to be imitated by them, if so be that all Poperie should endeauour to make their dominions the appointed field for warre: and if they cannot like Africanus, make the warres to ascend ouer into the countries of their enemies.
A more safe, easie, frugall, and honourable warre. But other arguments, and some more strong are not too popularly to be expressed.
Prince Anhalt is saide to bee gone to giue his attendance vpon Bucquoy, who is reported to bee fallen into melancholy (peraduenture adust) at Creams.

But rather the Loilorian Phormioes seeme to bee blamed then Bucquoy, because they make none ende with their talkatiue experience to violate the very Principles of Warre, and of Peace, and yet they must master the often tried practise of Commaunders in both, although perpetuall ruine manifesteth their folly to the world.

About this time was an assembly of Electors at Mulhouse; wherein Mentz, Colon, and Saxonie were present: and Tr • ers sent his Embassadour. They deliberated to turne away the misery that is likely to fall vpon the Emperour, &c.

But the Prince of Vinarie gathered souldiers for the Bohemians in the vnited prouinces of the Lowe Countries: and the States there deliberated of sending a Nauy into America, the Merchants bestowing a vast summe of money vpon this vse, which with hast they intend to employ, least any one should
ransacke the Campe before them.

When after this dismall day to Bucquoy, he was returned to Creames, the Cosacces began againe with most terrible fyring and spoyling to sharke into lower Austria: and sparing neither Protestants nor Papists, procured so great enuy to themselues amongst all, in so much that they were partly slaine by their owne fellowe souldiers: namely, the Wallons, for committing of sacriledge, and partly were sent prisoners to Creames.

The Emperour by Proclamation required the Austrians to take the oath of allegiance, or else to bee denounced and proceeded against as Rebels: but it is apparent, that as the Emperour propounded this in a bad time, so that they will followe the course of the world, most to regard the arising King of Bohemia.

And as in a falling house the lesser timber followeth the greater, so doth it befall the Emperour: for euen those Souldiers who sometime had tarried in Veteraui • , as wee saide afore, and could not obtaine passage, being repelled by the Counts of Veterauia, when they had also beene very troublesome to the countrey people in the territorie of Triers, endeauoured to passe ouer into the Diocesse of Colen: but the countrey
people resisted them with such force, that although they had fired some of their villages, yet the fire beeing neglected, they slew many of the souldiers, and compelled the residue to flie.

Of them also who hauing obtained passage, were come to the borders of Bauaria, some of them falling into sedition, rent their colours, and went to serue vnder Marquesse Onoltzbac, and the others returned home.

The Marquesse of Durlach with an Army of the vnited Electors and States is gone to Briscoue, and abideth in the middest betwixt Brisac and Friburg, and hath signified to the bordering States, that hee is commaunded to hinder the passage of souldiers into Alsatia.

Not long after Leopold the Arch Duke sent Embassadors to entreat passage for his souldiers, to whom the Marquesse answered, that hee could not: but that they should goe vnto On •• tzbac there to obtaine leaue.

It is also reported, and that by especiall good and great intelligence, that since Bucquoy his ouerthrowe, some three thousand Italians comming to Budwitz, and thence passing forward in Bohemia, were met by
some of the King of Bohemia his forces, where after skirmish they being rowted, fled backe againe to Budwitz, leauing dead behind them, about some fiue hundred of their company.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
